The more philosophically interesting observation here is that this, very easily, proves how wrong it is to assume that we're capable of 'living in the moment'. I don't notice the blur, the lack of information. It gets replaced with the new, the second image in my memory. My memory! Even within the literal blink of an eye, we only live in our memory. We never even percieve the present. Not even for such a fraction of a second, a literal fraction of a second, do we actually observe things as they are. Not even with a slight time delay - no, it's not the first image that lingers. That would mean we're just slow. We're not not just slow. Our sense of what is 'present' is slower than the capacity of our brain to calculate an image for us to percieve instead of reality. Before we even think we have percieved a moment, our brain has subconsciously recalculated what that moment contained. We do not perceive the real world unfiltered. A part of our brain we have no control over can easily censor fourty minutes of our every day. We'd never know if other aspects of what we perceive to be the real world was altered somehow.

I don't want to appear too nutty, I believe pretty strongly that our scientific model of the world is accurate. Gravity is a thing, I do believe firmly. God is not a thing, I also do believe firmly. Magic doesn't exist, neither does effective beyond placebo homeopathy and other fairy tales. I believe that we have pretty much proven and understood the basics of all of these things. But this does make you think about our ability to ever completely confirm that we aren't wrong about the most basic facts, more basic than any of these ideas, doesn't it?

Those 40 minutes are not "lost", you are still a rational human being, experiencing and emoting through life.
Its important to blink as well.
Even though our sensatory perception can be compared to a digital medium, on or off, 0 or 1, our human experience is always on, like analog.
Einstein was his most brightest and focused when he drifted away in thought unaware of things around him for instance.
That is why we can't memorize as easily with 100 browser tabs opened. We need time to grasp things in our brains.
That is why in face of pain, for instance, we sense every fraction of time passing, more than when we lazy off, and often remember those moments later better than the more amenable ones.
And because being too aware of our surroundings is not the be all end all of our being, how many "lost" moments are there spent by our anxiety obliging us to stare at 100 tabs we will not remember tomorrow that trigger absolutely no real creative, social, personal, economic productivity ?
Also, that would be the same as saying a blind person has its entire day lost.

I learned it's because our cone cells are in the middle of our eyes and they "see" color. Then we have rod cells around the cones that see B&W or washed out colors. But then our eyes lenses are in front of all of this and the way they refract light causes the cones to get sharp images and the rods to get slightly blurred ones, kind of like the edges of a magnifying glass frame. So I guess evolution decided whatever was directly in front of us was more important and peripherals aren't.

So your brain is taking the very first clock image you saw and placing it in place when you look back at the clock the second time. Kind of like Google keeping your search history in the search bar. I just understood what he meant with the snake illusion and saccadic memory. It's cool that it shows us just how much our eyes move, even when we think we're looking at one thing. I tested this by staring at the center of the pattern. The more I focus my vision the slower the snakes seem to move, and the more I look around the faster the snakes move.

I don't know whether you still monitor comments on this video, but there's another great saccadic masking illusion that's really easy to do. Sit down, and lean your head all the way to one side, and focus your attention on something tall, like a water bottle. Then, without blinking and in a smooth motion, rotate your head up and over to your other side, continuing to look at the water bottle. It will look like reality is moving at about 4 fps.

Let's do the math.
40 minutes a day times 365 days = 14600 minutes.
Lets say the average human lives to be about 80 years old.
so 14600 mintues times 80 years = 1168000
1168000 minutes sounds like a lot but lets break it down now.
1168000 minutes divided by 60 (to get the hours) = 19466.66 repeating
19466.67 hours (I rounded) divided by 24 (to get the days) = 811.11125
so about 811 days, divide it one more time by 365 and we get 2.2 ...

Your are right, but what i meant was, that you cant really achieve the perfect replication of nothing being seen between two different positions of the screen, and because of that sometimes first person games get a little jarring. Lets say the game is running at 60fps, no matter how fast the screen can move, you are going to get frames in between, the computer cannot predict where you are going to stop the mouse and replace the in between movement with the final place you are looking at.

Right on, the 80 milliseconds detail is what I was looking for.  The occurrence of this that always struck me the most was when it happens with a yellow stop light. :D

Because what you're actually perceiving as "now" is roughly 80 milliseconds in the past. So when you move your eyes, the brain waits until an image that makes sense appears, then posts that image as happening during the blur time. This all happens before the completed image of "now" (audio, touch, taste, vision, etc) is sent to your conscious mind and so you don't perceive the delay. And the taller you are, the longer each "now" takes to form. Weird, huh?

I have a question about this.  How can the brain take something one sees after a given point and place it in that given point, when the "experience" of that moment has already happened?  I understand the concept, I just don't understand how it's possible for the brain to "act retroactively", when it comes to what we experience in real time.  i.e., not working with memories.

It is indeed a memory thing...and a little bit of a "your brain is lying to you" thing. Your brain makes you "forget" the blur (unless you're trying really hard to notice it) and just tells you that you were looking at the second thing slightly longer than you actually were. Thus, if the second thing is "a clock," and you catch it just at the start of a new second, you get the second you're actually seeing, plus the small loop your brain put there and is insisting you were seeing the whole time.

@TheOnlyFairee It doesn't. It only takes you a fraction of a second to dart your eyes. For all intents and purposes, your eyes see at a framerate of about 60 frames per second. It only takes the eye a few frames to dart, but these frames end up incomprehensible to the brain. Therefore, the brain simply replaces these frames when the next frame you saw, and then you perceive this as the Stopped Clock Effect. Your brain processes the image this way before you're made aware of it.
